There were demonstrations in France today as transportation and utility workers went on strike.
It's the second time in the last month that the unions have staged a massive walkout across the country.
They're protesting President Nicolas Sarkozy's plan to end the special retirement deal enjoyed by many public sector workers.
The strike affected power and gas supplies.
But Eleanor Beardsley reports from Paris that the biggest impact was on public transport.
Paris was once again snarled in traffic as commuters tried to make their way to work without trains, buses or metro service.
Some Parisians spent the night in their offices, others turned to bikes, scooters and even rollerblades to get to work.
There were some 200 miles of traffic jams around the French capital during the morning rush hour.
Elsewhere in the city, the streets were jammed with demonstrating workers.
(SOUNDBITE OF PROTESTERS)
Workers in this march in the Montparnasse district said they took poorly paid, often difficult jobs on the promise of early retirement.
Half a million public employees are allowed to retire early after 37 1/2 years of employment.
These workers say they want to keep those special pensions.
State rail employee Didier Fontein(ph) says they'll keep the strike going for as long as it takes.
(Through translator) Today, Sarkozy is attacking us.
But in January, he's going to start attacking everyone's returns.
Believe me, soon, people are going to have to work 41 years before they can retire.
And why shouldn't all the French be able to retire after 37 and a half years?
France is a wealthy country.
So people should be able to work less.
From her book shop along Boulevard Montparnasse, Ahmel Lenier(ph) sneers at the demonstrators.
(Through translator) These strikes are disgusting and they punish everyone, especially regular business people like me.
I support Sarkozy's reforms 100 percent, and I know at least 60 percent of French people agree with me.
These people need to wake up.
There are harder things in life than driving a train.
Christophe Barbier, editor of L'Express magazine, says Sarkozy has staked his presidency on this fight.
(Through translator) If Sarkozy doesn't hold out on this one, his term is basically over after just six months in office.
He has built himself up as the leader of the force, to break with the past.
And if that all ends on this small but very symbolic issue, Sarkozy will be reduced to a paper tiger.
For NPR News, I'm Eleanor Beardsley in Paris.

VOA tells the story of America - not just stories about the government but stories about entrepreneurialism, health and science and technology in parts of the world where the Russians put a false narrative about the American experience and the American intentions and motives.
So you mentioned false narratives.
What is an example of a Russian false narrative that is harmful to the United States?
Well, for instance, the Russians - if you think about the hot war in Eastern Ukraine, the Russian narrative is that that's something that's been ginned up by the United States.
Oh, this is kind of classic conspiracy theory.
They're saying it's a false-flag operation.
Yeah.
It looks like Russia's interfering in eastern Ukraine.
But it's actually the United States doing it.
Right, yeah.
You can sort of put that approach against any number of issues.
You know, up is down.
Black is white - that kind of thing.
And so we're constantly fighting a battle every day in the face of propagandists around the world.
What tools does Russia use to get its narratives out?
Well Russia has a very, very well-financed media conglomerate.
You can see RT, Russia Today, here in the United States.
And sometimes it's much more subtle and nuanced than you might think.
It's a way of twisting a narrative or questioning a narrative that puts the United States at a disadvantage on an important issue.
Meaning they might throw in some facts, but they'll bend them a certain way.
Yes.
Is Russia investing big time in this kind of propaganda?
Oh, their investment in media and disinformation and propaganda would dwarf that of the United States - easily 10 to one.
Ten to one.
Yes.
Our agency, to give you an example, is funded at $750 million a year.
And we believe Russian-state media would be in the range of 10 times that.
How, if at all, have you dealt with the fact that you're trying to counter Russian propaganda?
And in recent months, on a number of instances, the president of the United States has appeared to take the Russian line and Russian narratives.
Well, we report that just as any news organization.
It's our job to report all sides of a story.
And we have the greatest respect for whoever is president.
And their point of view is something that's newsworthy.
And we report that.
I'm thinking about just the other day.
The president is talking with Bill O'Reilly of Fox News.
They talk about Vladimir Putin, the Russian president.
O'Reilly says he's a killer.
And Trump says, you think we're so innocent?
And Russia watchers said, well, that's actually the Russian narrative - that Russia tries to tear down the United States and say the United States is just as bad as Russia.
And, again, that's something that we report like other news organizations.
We report all sides of a story and do - the analysis is necessary for people to understand exactly what's being said and what the reaction to that is.
Is that an accurate description of a big Russia narrative - that the United States is morally compromised, and if you think Russia is bad, the United States is bad, too?
You know, I can't say for sure.
To be honest with you, it would be a speculation.
But it's a challenge every day to broadcast truth against fiction.
John Lansing, who is CEO of the Broadcasting Board of Governors, overseeing the Voice of America, thanks very much.
